title: 108_hr4550
content: The Act titled "Safe, Efficient, Coordinated, Unified, Revitalized, Enhanced Visa Waiver Act" allows for electronic submission of biographical information by visa waiver participants. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish an electronic system for visa waiver program participants to submit biographical information before entering the US. The system must electronically determine eligibility. The electronic system will determine eligibility for nonimmigrant visitors to the US within 30 minutes. Carriers and corporations will have obligations under the system. The system requires carriers and corporations to electronically inquire about an alien passenger's visa status before embarkation. The electronic response must be provided within 90 seconds. The system deployment should occur promptly after the enactment of the Act. The Secretary of Homeland Security will establish a fee for aliens to cover the costs of the system. Consultation with a private sector group is required for system development. SEC. 3. CHANGE TO REQUIREMENT FOR READERS AND SCANNERS AT PORTS OF ENTRY. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act requires the installation of biometric equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry for visa and entry document authentication by October 26, 2004. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act mandates the installation of biometric equipment and software at all U.S. ports of entry for passport authentication. The Technology Standard Implementation Deadline in the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act has been extended from 2004 to 2005. Additionally, a Limited Good Faith Waiver has been implemented. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act has extended the Technology Standard Implementation Deadline to 2005 and introduced a Limited Good Faith Waiver allowing the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions to countries making progress on passport issuance. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions to countries making progress on passport issuance, considering factors certified by the Secretary of State. The Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act allows the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant extensions to countries making progress on passport issuance, considering factors certified by the Secretary of State. Countries must make a good faith effort to meet requirements by specific deadlines, including starting a pilot program for issuing compliant passports. In 2006, the Secretary of Homeland Security, in consultation with the Secretary of State, is required to issue an initial report by October 26, 2005, and a final report by April 25, 2006, on countries' progress in meeting passport issuance requirements. SEC. 6. TECHNICAL AND CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amends Section 303 of the Enhanced Border Security and Visa Entry Reform Act to replace "Attorney General" with "Secretary of Homeland Security".
